data.title: Egypt stock market rising
data.description:
(1 Oct 2017) LEAD IN:
The Egyptian stock market is rising on the first session of the week.

STORY-LINE:
The EGX 30, the main benchmark index for the Egyptian stock exchange, opened on 13,888 points this morning.
It has risen to 13,974 points, an increase of 0.62 percent (as at 11:30 GMT).
Dealer Naglaa Farag says the rise is "due to purchases by Arabs and local individuals, while foreign investors and financial institutions are gaining profit".
She describes the trading volume as "moderate".


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/90494689a1136a334efb7821bf24b9ce 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Voters cast ballots in Catalonia referendum
data.description:
(1 Oct 2017) Polling has begun in a banned referendum on Catalonia's independence, with the first voters casting ballots amidst cheers in some of the designated polling stations.
Parents, children and activist volunteers had occupied some of the 2,315 schools and other facilities to avoid closure from police acting on court orders.
Spain's Constitutional Court ordered the vote to be suspended and central authorities say it's illegal. 
Regional separatist leaders are holding it anyway and promising to declare independence if the "yes" side wins, and have called on 5.3 million eligible voters to cast ballots.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/3e49fe1f219c7cc9fcb1bbc2a86e2178 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Protest against referendum in Madrid's Sol square
data.description:
(1 Oct 2017) People rallied in Sol Square in Madrid on Sunday to protest against the Catalan independence vote. 
The protest came as Spanish government and its security forces were trying to prevent voting, which is backed by Catalan regional authorities. 
In Barcelona, several people were injured as Spanish riot police smashed their way into polling stations and fired rubber bullets at protesters outside a polling station. 
Spain's Constitutional Court has suspended the vote. 
Regional separatist leaders pledged to hold it anyway, promising to declare independence if the "yes" side wins, and have called on 5.3 million eligible voters to cast ballots.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/0adba4cf9306f53db4179b4cccc916eb 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: DFM falls 0.52 percent
data.description:
(1 Oct 2017) LEAD IN 
The Dubai Financial Market has fallen on the first session of the week.

STORY-LINE
The DFM closed on 3,545.40 points at the end of the first session of the week, a drop of 0.52 percent.
Shares in GFH Financial Group fell by 4.22 percent, Emaar stock dropped 0.94 percent, while Air Arabia shares were unchanged.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/a2493a7497c750ad8c6f8b0a0aec9ae5 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Mass protest in Hong Kong on National Day
data.description:
(1 Oct 2017) Pro-democracy groups protested in Hong Kong on Sunday against what they described as the authorities' "authoritarian rule" and to demand that the secretary of justice step down for eroding the rule of law after new stiffer sentences were imposed on student leaders.
Thousands of protesters set off from Victoria Park as the territory marked its National Day holiday. 
Justice Secretary Rimsky Yuen appealed a decision by a lower court to hand out only suspended prison terms and community service to three leaders of the 2014 pro-democracy protests over their roles in the so-called Occupy movement.
The court of appeal instead imposed between six and eight months of imprisonment on activists Joshua Wong, Nathan Law and Alex Chow. 
The former British colony maintains civil liberties unseen on mainland China including freedom of speech following its 1997 handover, but many residents fear Beijing is tightening its grip.
Some young activists have started promoting the once-unthinkable notion of independence from mainland China after massive pro-democracy protests ended without resolution in 2014. 
There's almost no chance of success but their ideas have alarmed China's Communist leaders in Beijing.
Hong Kong's Beijing-backed government has clamped down on such sentiment, including using the courts to get two newly elected pro-independence lawmakers disqualified from office last year for making improper oaths of office.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/ded615b165287cbdc57ef2b9e071f534 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: WFP: Bangladesh needs immediate help for Rohingya
data.description:
(1 Oct 2017) The head of the United Nations World Food Programme on Sunday urged the international community to step up its support for the relief operation for Rohingya refugees in Bangladesh or risk "a catastrophic humanitarian disaster".
More than half a million Rohingya Muslims have fled into the country in little more than a month to escape a Myanmar military operation so brutal it has been condemned as ethnic cleansing. 
The crackdown was in response to a series of deadly attacks on security posts by Muslim insurgents.
Authorities have housed the refugees in a number of existing camps near the border but the huge numbers and the sheer speed of the exodus have created acute needs, including food.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/62c934d3c5431588c2a43c6213057291 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Ballots cast as Catalonia votes in referendum
data.description:
(1 Oct 2017) Hundreds of Catalans did manage to cast their ballot in the disputed independence referendum on Sunday, despite Spanish police trying to halt the plesbicite by smashing their way into some polling stations and firing rubber bullets at protesters outside one polling station.
Tension had been on the rise since the vote was called in early September, crystalising years of defiance by separatists in the affluent region, which contributes mightily to Spain's economy. 
As one of Spain's 17 autonomous regions, Catalonia enjoys ample rights, but key areas such as infrastructure and taxes are in the hands of Madrid. 
Separatist Catalans have long complained of contributing too much to the state while not getting enough in return.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/8a5a71d35c1854b8ca5a7c3352da01f4 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: 'Burqa ban' law signals rightward political turn in Austria
data.description:
(1 Oct 2017) A law prohibiting any kind of full face covering - known popularly as the "Burka Ban" - takes effect in Austria on Sunday.
Strong support for it portends political upheaval in the 15 October national elections, with parties campaigning on an anti-migrant message poised to win and form a coalition government.
Such a rightward swing would have European Union-wide significance, not only ending what has been near-consistent governance by centrist parties in Austria since World War II but also strengthening the position of countries that have taken a hard line on migration.
And with Germany's far-right and anti-migrant AfD party winning seats in the national parliament for the first time last week, any rightward turn in Austria would increase concerns among more moderate political forces within the European Union.
The law is known formally as "Prohibition for the Covering of the Face".
It applies to all coverings, including ski masks off the slopes, surgical masks outside hospitals and clown masks, except for costume parties. 
It carries a maximum fine of 150 euros (nearly 180 US dollars) and police are authorised to use force with those resisting.
But its popular name reflects what most people associate with it - a paradox given that full veils remain rare in Austria despite the 2015 migrant surge into Europe. 
And Muslim community women leaders see arguments that it helps suppressed women as insincere.
Support for the law is strong, reflecting anti-Muslim voter attitudes that have put the parties fomenting such sentiments in front.
The two parties that critics link to anti-Muslim sentiment are the traditionally xenophobic Freedom Party and the People's Party.
The latter avoids the Freedom Party's inflammatory talk, but has swung radically from the centre to echo that party's positions on migration under its new leader, Sebastian Kurz.
Left struggling is the Social Democratic Party, even though it now is the majority partner in the government coalition with the People's Party.
Under Chancellor Christian Kern, the Social Democrats have been focusing on social topics and claiming success for Austria's recent economic upturn. 
Beyond his own liberal stance, Kern has no choice, with pro-migrant sentiment strong within the party.
But his message is not coming across well. 
A Unique Research poll of 1,500 respondents published on Thursday - with a 2.5 percentage point error margin - showed the Social Democrats with 27 percent support, ahead of the Freedom Party at 25 percent, but trailing the People's Party with 34 percent.
Although the People's Party was part of the government coalition that opened its borders to more than 100,000 migrants in 2015, the party under Kurz now says that "the political establishment failed in dealing with the refugee crisis".


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/fe35b27c9ec4b540f70ed206c3a614e3 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Germany celebrates 1st same-sex weddings after law change
data.description:
(1 Oct 2017) Germany celebrated its first same-sex weddings on Sunday, after a new law came into force putting gay and lesbian couples on an equal legal footing with heterosexual couples.
Town halls in Berlin, Hamburg and elsewhere opened their doors to mark the event, made possible by a surprise vote in parliament three months earlier.
At Berlin's Schoeneberg district, about 60 guests and an equal number of journalists packed into the town hall's "Golden Room" to witness the marriage of Karl Kreile and his partner of 38 years, Bodo Mende.
The grooms entered the room to the popular "Wedding March" by 19th-century German composer Felix Mendelssohn, before saying their vows and signing the marriage documents to applause and cheers from the assembled guests.
Kreile, 59, and Mende, 60, had been campaigning for gay rights for decades and said they were honoured to be the first same-sex couple to marry in Germany. 
After cutting the wedding cake - featuring a rainbow flag and the words "marriage for all" - the couple planned to hold a small reception and fly to Vienna later in the week for a five-day honeymoon.
The couple first registered their partnership in 2002, when Germany introduced registered partnerships.
But those gave same-sex couples fewer rights than heterosexual couples who married.
Chancellor Angela Merkel long opposed same-sex marriages, only agreeing to a free vote in parliament on the matter in June, shortly before national elections.
The bill, which enjoyed strong public support, passed by a wide margin, with 393 lawmakers voting in favour of marriage equality and 226 - including Merkel - voting against.
Some hurdles remain, including the fact that women can't automatically recognise motherhood of a lesbian partner's child, and the software used to record marriages doesn't currently allow for two entries with the same sex.
Still, those attending Sunday's ceremony in Schoeneberg said Germany's decision to allow same-sex marriages - the 23rd country worldwide to do so - was a big step.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/4cdb0a178d0e9a40b6f268eb5c2c0e1d 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Catalan leader greets supporters after voting
data.description:
(1 Oct 2017) Catalonia's regional leader has condemned the Spanish police crackdown on people trying to vote in the disputed independence referendum.
Catalan President Carles Puigdemont said that "police brutality will shame forever the Spanish state" after police smashed their way into voting centers and fired rubber bullets to disperse crowds.
Police have been ordered to prevent the vote from taking place.
Puigdemont was welcomed by cheering crowds at the gymnasium where police broke in to halt voting. The Catalan leader was meant to vote there in Sant Julia e Ramis but had to choose a different polling center instead.
He said the Spanish government had damaged itself by its actions.
Puigdemont said that "today, the Spanish state has lost much more than what it had already lost, while Catalonia has won."


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/20164ef99dbed537c08f825008b7a31b 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Millo: Spanish National Guard, police acted "with professionalism"
data.description:
(1 Oct 2017) Spanish riot police smashed their way into polling stations to try to halt a disputed independence referendum in Catalonia on Sunday and fired rubber bullets at protesters outside a Barcelona polling station. 
Several people were injured.
The officers fired the rubber bullets while trying to clear protesters who were trying to prevent National Police cars from leaving after police confiscated ballot boxes from the voting centre. 
The Spanish government has ordered police to stop the voting process, saying it was illegal.
Catalan officials said 38 people were treated for mostly minor injuries. 
An AP photographer saw several people who had been injured during the scuffles outside Barcelona's Rius i Taule school, where some voters had cast ballots before police arrived
Catalan President Carles Puigdemont condemned the crackdown.
Enric Millo, the Spanish government's representative in the region, said police and National Guard forces acted "professionally" to enforce court orders. 
He said any attempt to claim the referendum as valid was doomed.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/bc1d926a427430f235f8af0ba9ab8270 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Voters casts ballots in Vic in Catalan referendum
data.description:
(1 Oct 2017) Hundreds of Catalans began gathering outside polling stations in the early hours of Sunday as a disputed independence referendum takes place in Catalonia. 
In Vic, a town roughly one hour away from Barcelona, the heart of the independence voters beats as never before. 
Many people surrounded a school as Catalan police, known as "mossos" approached the organisers to take note of the situation only to leave shortly afterwards, leaving only a wave of applause behind as people chanted "I will vote."
Polls had been expected to open at 9 am local time (0700 GMT).
However, due to connection problems with the app especially created by the Catalan Government for the day, people were prevented from voting as soon as the doors were open. 
Almost two hours later people began casting their ballots. 
Electoral volunteers at various polling stations said they were unable to access census data because the website that hosted it was down, while the internet service had been cut in some of the stations.
Across the region, parents, children and activist volunteers had occupied some of the 2,315 schools and other facilities to avoid closure from police acting on court orders.
Spain's Constitutional Court ordered the vote to be suspended and central authorities said it was illegal. 
Regional separatist leaders are holding it anyway and promising to declare independence if the "yes" side wins.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/c54622d58eb6c7f89629e96b6ae465c5 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

asset.author: AP Archive

data.title: Police raid Girona polling station, people injured
data.description:
(1 Oct 2017) Spanish riot police smashed their way into a polling station near the Catalan city of Girona on Sunday.
Civil Guard riot police with shields used a hammer to smash the glass of the front door of the voting centre and lock cutters to force their way in. 
Scuffles erupted outside between police and people waiting to vote at the polling centre in Sant Julia de Ramis. 
The Spanish government has ordered police to stop the voting process, saying it was illegal.
Catalan officials said 38 people were treated for mostly minor injuries across the region.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/0b1cfcb9bf2dcd528504e5085771782a 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

Civil Guard riot police with shields used a hammer to smash the glass of the front door of the voting centre and lock cutters to force their way in. 
Scuffles erupted outside between police and people waiting to vote at the polling centre in Sant Julia de Ramis. 
The Spanish government has ordered police to stop the voting process, saying it was illegal.
Catalan officials said 38 people were treated for mostly minor injuries across the region.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/0b1cfcb9bf2dcd528504e5085771782a 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork
asset.author: AP Archive

data.title: Egypt stock market rising
data.description:
(1 Oct 2017) LEAD IN:
The Egyptian stock market is rising on the first session of the week.

STORY-LINE:
The EGX 30, the main benchmark index for the Egyptian stock exchange, opened on 13,888 points this morning.
It has risen to 13,974 points, an increase of 0.62 percent (as at 11:30 GMT).
Dealer Naglaa Farag says the rise is "due to purchases by Arabs and local individuals, while foreign investors and financial institutions are gaining profit".
She describes the trading volume as "moderate".


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/90494689a1136a334efb7821bf24b9ce 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Marilyn Manson hurt onstage during New York show
data.description:
(1 Oct 2017) MARILYN MANSON HURT ONSTAGE DURING NEW YORK SHOW
Marilyn Manson's representative says the singer was injured in a mishap on stage during a New York City performance and taken to a hospital Saturday (30 SEPT. 2017).
Variety reports that Manson was performing a cover of the Eurythmics' "Sweet Dreams (Are Made of This)" when he began to climb a podium, causing it to wobble. Manson fell backward and the prop fell on him. Soon the house and stage lights went off for several minutes and came back on with an announcer saying the show was over "due to injury."
It was not immediately clear whether any of Manson's concert dates will be postponed due to the injury.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/4f914bcb6d9e17f8589df62e5834a1bd 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Protest against referendum in Madrid's Sol square
data.description:
(1 Oct 2017) People rallied in Sol Square in Madrid on Sunday to protest against the Catalan independence vote. 
The protest came as Spanish government and its security forces were trying to prevent voting, which is backed by Catalan regional authorities. 
In Barcelona, several people were injured as Spanish riot police smashed their way into polling stations and fired rubber bullets at protesters outside a polling station. 
Spain's Constitutional Court has suspended the vote. 
Regional separatist leaders pledged to hold it anyway, promising to declare independence if the "yes" side wins, and have called on 5.3 million eligible voters to cast ballots.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/0adba4cf9306f53db4179b4cccc916eb 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

asset.author: AP Archive

data.title: Spain deputy PM: Police action proportional and firm
data.description:
(1 Oct 2017) Spain's deputy prime minister on Sunday said Spanish police have intervened with "firmness and proportionality" against the Catalan vote on secession.
Soraya Saenz de Santamaria said authorities acted in a professional and proportional way, and they weren't going after voters, but referendum material.
She accused the Catalan government which is trying to hold the referendum of behaving irresponsibly.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/af1a4c3d27563040fb7551fd5ac3293d 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Scenes at Marseille train station amid security alert
data.description:
(1 Oct 2017) French police on Sunday warned people to avoid Marseille's main train station amid reports of a knife attack.
Saint Charles train station was evacuated and police on their official Twitter account said an operation was under way.
No other details were immediately available.
French television station BFM TV reported at least one person had been stabbed and that the assailant had been shot dead.
The interior minister tweeted he was travelling to the scene of the attack.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/6037a17c27f3a05c8f2e21ce3da0126d 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Mass protest in Hong Kong on National Day
data.description:
(1 Oct 2017) Pro-democracy groups protested in Hong Kong on Sunday against what they described as the authorities' "authoritarian rule" and to demand that the secretary of justice step down for eroding the rule of law after new stiffer sentences were imposed on student leaders.
Thousands of protesters set off from Victoria Park as the territory marked its National Day holiday. 
Justice Secretary Rimsky Yuen appealed a decision by a lower court to hand out only suspended prison terms and community service to three leaders of the 2014 pro-democracy protests over their roles in the so-called Occupy movement.
The court of appeal instead imposed between six and eight months of imprisonment on activists Joshua Wong, Nathan Law and Alex Chow. 
The former British colony maintains civil liberties unseen on mainland China including freedom of speech following its 1997 handover, but many residents fear Beijing is tightening its grip.
Some young activists have started promoting the once-unthinkable notion of independence from mainland China after massive pro-democracy protests ended without resolution in 2014. 
There's almost no chance of success but their ideas have alarmed China's Communist leaders in Beijing.
Hong Kong's Beijing-backed government has clamped down on such sentiment, including using the courts to get two newly elected pro-independence lawmakers disqualified from office last year for making improper oaths of office.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/ded615b165287cbdc57ef2b9e071f534 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Festival celebrates ancient Queen
data.description:
(1 Oct 2017) LEAD IN:
Alexandria has held a special event to celebrate the ancient leader Cleopatra.
Actors paraded through the streets to bring attention to the sunken palace of Cleopatra which lies on the seabed of the city's harbour.

STORY-LINE:
Dressed in the costumes of their ancient ancestors, Egyptians parade through the streets of Alexandria.
Actors are playing the soldiers and handmaids of Queen Cleopatra, the last ruler of the Ptolemaic dynasty.
The legendary leader emerges, pulled past the crowds on a golden throne by her soldiers.
The event has been named 'Cleopatra's Dream' and it has taken a lot of effort to make sure this huge procession works like clockwork.
Actor Mahmoud Abd Elaziz plays the soldiers' commander.
"We did 17 rehearsals: ten in the studios and seven outdoors. It was not easy," he says.
The parade passes along the Alexandria Corniche, from the Citadel of Qaitbay towards the diving centre at the Eastern Port.
This event is being held to draw attention to the sunken city of Cleopatra in the sea around Alexandria. 
Hundreds of lost antiquities have been found in Alexandria's coastal waters in recent years. In 2015, over 200 treasures from Ancient Egyptian times were discovered.
It adds to the country's rich history - something the actors have studied closely for their roles.
"We studied the things they used like jewellery and colours. For example the colour blue symbolises the sky, and they were always aiming for eternal life," says Shery Kamal, who plays a maid.
"We also studied other things like make-up and the importance of the scarab."
The celebration comes hot on the heels of World Tourism Day and has been organised in coordination with the Ministry of Tourism and the Tourism Promotion Authority.
Since the uprising that toppled former president Hosni Mubarak in 2011, Egypt's tourism industry has taken a heavy toll.
In 2016, in an attempt to bring back foreign visitors, the country's Ministry of Antiquities announced a plan to establish what it dubbed the world's first underwater museum to showcase the submerged relics of Alexandria's ancient treasures.
The plan has not yet been carried out, but the director of today's show hopes events like this might help attract more visitors.
"We have created a street carnival that represents the dream of Cleopatra in order to activate tourism. We believe that there is nothing better than art to stimulate tourism," says Fady Nour.
Cleopatra boards her golden boat and heads out into the sea.
The ancient leader's palace and other buildings and monuments lie strewn on the seabed in the harbour of Alexandria, the second largest city of Egypt. 
Since 1994, archaeologists have been exploring the ruins, one of the richest underwater excavations in the Mediterranean, discovering around 6,000 artefacts. 
Perhaps this watery treasure trove could be the secret to bringing tourists back to the city.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/77d36ca8aa111070f3cc89cfd0ee906f 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork
